title: PLOWING A FIELD WITH A SMALL TRACTOR. DID IT WORK?

subtasks: Sit on the tractor seat.
Engage the single bottom plow attachment.
Adjust the hydraulic top link to level the plow.
Monitor the depth of the plow during operation.
Adjust speed to prevent bogging down in soil.
Navigate rows while plowing, including following previous rows.
Start plowing from the outside and work in towards the center.
Listen to the tractor's feedback during operation.
Use the tractor's various tools (e.g., front end loader) for preparation.
Apply sheer bolt protection to prevent damage from obstructions.
Research and understand proper plowing techniques (e.g., starting from the middle and working outward).
Adapt to the limited power of a smaller tractor when tooling the land.

tasks.task: Creating a food plot for deer.
subtasks: Coordinate with wildlife management experts (e.g., Jeff Sturgis, Whitetail Habitat Solutions).
Design the food plot layout (including types of crops like greens, brassicas, buckwheat, radishes).
Plan the timing for planting the food plot (e.g., later in the summer).
Consider past land use (formerly a cattle pasture) when developing the plot.
Anticipate future deer behavior (attracting them to the center for hunting purposes).
Monitor and adjust the plan based on initial plowing experiences (e.g., correcting plowing technique after first attempts).
Familiarize with the tractor's specifications (e.g., 25 horsepower).
Understand compatibility issues with quick hitch plows.
Use of sheer bolt protection in plowing.
Operate the tractor efficiently for the task at hand (e.g., gauging speed and power output).
Engage with customers and discuss product knowledge (e.g., pricing, availability).
Utilize resources (e.g., website, videos) for troubleshooting and expanding knowledge.
